credentials.name: Dr. Andy Kitlowski
credentials.title: Emergency Medicine Physician
credentials.bio: Board-certified emergency physician with expertise in clinical decision support and emergency medicine informatics. Passionate about leveraging AI to improve patient care and reduce cognitive load for clinicians.

certifications.name: Fellow of American College of Emergency Physicians

demoWidget.title: Try It Now
demoWidget.subtitle: Select a clinical scenario and ask questions just like you would in a real consult. No signup required.

scenarios.title: Neurosyphilis Workup
scenarios.description: Suspected neurosyphilis in a patient with reactive syphilis serology and neurologic symptoms
scenarios.openingMessage: I see a 42yo male with reactive syphilis serology (RPR 1:128), confusion, and bilateral vision changes. The key question: does this patient need a lumbar puncture to evaluate for neurosyphilis?
sampleQueries: What are the CSF criteria for neurosyphilis?

lp|lumbar|puncture|csf.content:
**Lumbar Puncture Decision â€” CDC 2021 Guidelines**

Perform LP if ANY of the following:

1. **Neurologic symptoms** (confusion, vision changes, headache)
2. **Ocular symptoms** (uveitis, optic neuritis, vision loss)
3. **Otologic symptoms** (hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo)
4. **Treatment failure** (rising titers after appropriate therapy)

**This patient:** Has confusion + vision changes = **LP indicated**

**CSF Studies to Send:**
â€¢ CSF-VDRL (specific, but insensitive)
â€¢ CSF FTA-ABS/TP-PA (highly sensitive)
â€¢ CSF cell count and protein
â€¢ CSF glucose

treatment|therapy|penicillin.content:
**Neurosyphilis Treatment â€” CDC 2021**

**Aqueous Crystalline Penicillin G**
â€¢ 18-24 million units IV daily
â€¢ Given as 3-4 million units IV q4h OR continuous infusion
â€¢ Duration: **10-14 days**

**Alternative (if penicillin allergy):**
â€¢ Desensitization to penicillin (preferred)
â€¢ OR Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily x 10-14 days (limited data)

**Follow-up:**
â€¢ Recheck CSF at 6 months
â€¢ CSF-VDRL should decrease or be nonreactive

ocular|eye|vision|uveitis.content:
**Ocular Syphilis Considerations**

Ocular syphilis is a form of neurosyphilis â€” **treat as CNS disease**

**Key Points:**
â€¢ Can affect any ocular structure (uveitis, optic neuritis, retinitis)
â€¢ May occur at any stage of infection
â€¢ LP recommended even without other neurologic symptoms
â€¢ Urgent ophthalmology consult

**Treatment:** Same as neurosyphilis (IV penicillin G)

criteria|diagnosis|positive.content:
**Neurosyphilis Diagnostic Criteria**

Definite neurosyphilis requires:

1. **Reactive CSF-VDRL** (specific, but insensitive ~30-70%)
   - OR reactive CSF FTA-ABS with elevated CSF WBC/protein

2. **Elevated CSF WBC** (>5 cells/Î¼L)

3. **Elevated CSF protein** (>45 mg/dL)

**Note:** CSF FTA-ABS is highly sensitive (~95%) but less specific â€” treponemal antibodies may persist after treatment.

default.content:
Based on this case of suspected neurosyphilis with neurologic symptoms, I recommend:

1. **Perform LP** â€” indicated due to confusion and vision changes
2. **Send CSF studies:** VDRL, FTA-ABS, cell count, protein, glucose
3. **Start empiric IV penicillin G** 18-24 million units daily x 10-14 days
4. **Ophthalmology consult** for vision changes
5. **HIV testing** â€” concurrent HIV infection affects management

Would you like details on CSF interpretation or treatment protocols?

scenarios.title: PE Risk Stratification
scenarios.description: Hemodynamically stable patient with confirmed pulmonary embolism
scenarios.openingMessage: 67yo female with submassive PE confirmed on CTPA. Hemodynamically stable currently. Key decision: risk stratification and whether to pursue systemic thrombolysis vs anticoagulation alone.

risk|pesi|spesi|score.content:
**Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI)**

| Factor | Points |
|--------|--------|
| Age (years) | +1/year |
| Male sex | +10 |
| Cancer | +30 |
| Heart failure | +20 |
| Chronic lung disease | +20 |
| HR >110 | +20 |
| SBP <100 | +30 |
| RR >30 | +20 |
| Temp <36Â°C | +20 |
| Altered mental status | +60 |
| SpO2 <90% | +20 |

**This patient:** Age 67 + HR 108 + SpO2 92% = **â‰¥67 points (Class III-IV)**

**sPESI simplified:** Age>80, cancer, CHF, CLD, HR>110, SBP<100, SpO2<90% = **â‰¥1 point = higher risk**

tpa|thrombolysis|lysis|systemic.content:
**Thrombolysis in Submassive PE â€” Risk Stratification**

**Absolute indications (massive PE):**
â€¢ Sustained hypotension (SBP <90 or drop â‰¥40 for >15 min)
â€¢ Cardiogenic shock

**Submassive PE â€” Consider thrombolysis if:**
â€¢ RV dysfunction on echo/CT + elevated troponin/BDNP
â€¢ Clinical deterioration despite anticoagulation
â€¢ High PESI/sPESI score

**This patient:** Submassive, hemodynamically stable â†’
**Start anticoagulation** (heparin infusion or DOAC)
**Monitor closely** for deterioration

**Dell Seton protocol:** Systemic tPA only if massive PE or clinical decompensation.

anticoagulation|heparin|apixaban|rivarox.content:
**PE Anticoagulation Options**

**Parenteral (initial):**
â€¢ Unfractionated heparin â€” preferred if thrombolysis being considered
â€¢ LMWH (enoxaparin) â€” if no anticipated procedures

**Oral (maintenance):**
â€¢ Apixaban 10mg BID x 7 days, then 5mg BID
â€¢ Rivaroxaban 15mg BID x 21 days, then 20mg daily
â€¢ DOACs preferred for hemodynamically stable patients

**Duration:**
â€¢ Provoked PE (surgery): 3 months
â€¢ Unprovoked PE: Consider extended therapy

**Contraindications to DOACs:**
â€¢ Active bleeding, severe renal impairment, antiphospholipid syndrome

rv|right|ventricle|strain|echo.content:
**RV Dysfunction in PE**

**Echo findings:**
â€¢ RV dilation (RV/LV ratio >0.9 or >1.0)
â€¢ Septal flattening (D-sign)
â€¢ McConnell's sign (RV free wall akinesis with apical sparing)
â€¢ TR with elevated RVSP

**CT findings:**
â€¢ RV/LV diameter ratio >0.9
â€¢ Septal bowing toward LV

**Significance:** RV dysfunction indicates hemodynamic compromise and is associated with increased mortality. Consider escalation of care.

default.content:
This 67yo with confirmed submassive PE requires:

1. **Immediate anticoagulation** â€” UFH infusion if considering thrombolysis, otherwise LMWH or DOAC
2. **Risk stratification** â€” PESI score, RV assessment
3. **Admission** â€” telemetry for monitoring
4. **Contraindications check** â€” bleeding risk, recent surgery

**Key decision:** Systemic thrombolysis NOT indicated currently (hemodynamically stable). Reserve for massive PE or clinical deterioration.

Would you like help with anticoagulation dosing or monitoring parameters?

scenarios.title: Pneumothorax POCUS
scenarios.description: Traumatic pneumothorax evaluation with point-of-care ultrasound
scenarios.openingMessage: 28yo male s/p MVC with right chest trauma. Decreased breath sounds on the right. Bedside ultrasound shows absent lung sliding and a lung point. This is a traumatic pneumothorax.
sampleQueries: Do I need a chest tube?

tube|chest|thoracostomy|drain.content:
**Chest Tube Indications â€” Traumatic Pneumothorax**

**Absolute indications:**
â€¢ Respiratory distress or compromise
â€¢ Hemodynamic instability
â€¢ Tension physiology
â€¢ Progressive enlargement on imaging

**Relative indications (OBS vs TUBE):**
â€¢ Size >2-3 cm at apex
â€¢ Positive pressure ventilation required
â€¢ Need for air transport
â€¢ Patient unreliable for follow-up

**This patient:** Small pneumothorax on POCUS, hemodynamically stable, not on ventilator â†’ **May observe** with serial exams.

**Observation criteria:**
â€¢ Admit 12-24h for monitoring
â€¢ Supplemental O2 (promotes reabsorption)
â€¢ Repeat CXR in 6-12 hours
â€¢ Immediate intervention if deterioration

size|measure|cm|measurement.content:
**Pneumothorax Size Estimation**

**POCUS estimation:**
â€¢ Small: <2 cm interpleural distance at apex
â€¢ Large: >2 cm interpleural distance

**Supine CXR (Collins method):**
â€¢ Approximate size = 4.2 + (4.7 Ã— A + B + C)
  - A = interpleural distance at apex
  - B = at mid-clavicular line
  - C = at base

**CT (most accurate):
â€¢ Measures actual volume

**Clinical significance:**
â€¢ <2 cm (approx 15%): Often observe
â€¢ >2 cm or clinical symptoms: Consider drainage

observe|observation|watch|wait.content:
**Observation Criteria for Traumatic Pneumothorax**

**Candidates for observation:**
âœ“ Small pneumothorax (<2 cm or <15%)
âœ“ Hemodynamically stable
âœ“ No respiratory distress
âœ“ Not requiring positive pressure ventilation
âœ“ Reliable patient with close follow-up

**Observation protocol:**
â€¢ Admit for monitoring (12-24 hours)
â€¢ High-flow O2 (promotes nitrogen washout)
â€¢ Serial physical exams
â€¢ Repeat CXR in 6-12 hours

**Stop points for observation:**
âœ— Clinical deterioration
âœ— PTX enlargement on repeat imaging
âœ— Need for positive pressure ventilation
âœ— Development of hemothorax

poCUS|ultrasound|lung|sliding.content:
**POCUS for Pneumothorax â€” Key Findings**

**Normal lung:**
â€¢ Lung sliding (seashore sign on M-mode)
â€¢ Comet tail artifacts (B-lines)

**Pneumothorax:**
â€¢ **Absent lung sliding** â€” most sensitive
â€¢ **Stratosphere sign** on M-mode (barcode sign)
â€¢ **Lung point** â€” pathognomonic (100% specific)
â€¢ Absent B-lines

**Extended FAST views:**
â€¢ Anterior 2nd-4th intercostal spaces (most sensitive for anterior PTX)
â€¢ Include lateral chest wall for complete evaluation

**Limitations:**
â€¢ Subcutaneous emphysema obscures view
â€¢ Lateral/small PTX may be missed anteriorly
â€¢ Operator dependent

default.content:
For this traumatic pneumothorax on POCUS:

1. **Confirm findings** â€” Absent sliding + lung point = definite PTX
2. **Assess size** â€” POCUS limited for size, get CXR/CT if clinical impact uncertain
3. **Clinical status** â€” Stable vitals, no distress â†’ observation likely appropriate
4. **High-flow O2** â€” Promotes reabsorption
5. **Monitor** â€” Serial exams, repeat imaging in 6-12 hours

**Tube thoracostomy** indicated if: respiratory distress, enlargement, need for PPV, or hemothorax.

Want specific guidance on chest tube size or insertion site?

scenarios.title: Basic Echo Views
scenarios.openingMessage: 55yo male with chest pain and hypotension (88/56). JVD present. You need to perform a bedside echo to assess for pericardial effusion, RV dilation, and global LV function.
sampleQueries: How do I see the effusion?

views|windows|basic|standard.content:
**5 Essential POCUS Echo Views**

**1. Parasternal Long Axis (PLAX)**
â€¢ Probe: 3rd-4th LICS, left sternal border
â€¢ Indicator to right shoulder
â€¢ Shows: LV, LA, MV, AV, RVOT, pericardium

**2. Parasternal Short Axis (PSAX)**
â€¢ Rotate 90Â° from PLAX
â€¢ Multiple levels: MV, papillary muscles, apex
â€¢ Shows: LV function (circular), septal motion

**3. Apical 4-Chamber (A4C)**
â€¢ Probe: cardiac apex (5th ICS, MCL)
â€¢ Indicator to left shoulder
â€¢ Shows: All 4 chambers, AV valves, pericardium

**4. Subcostal 4-Chamber**
â€¢ Probe: subxiphoid, flat orientation
â€¢ Indicator to left
â€¢ Shows: All 4 chambers, IVC, pericardium

**5. IVC View**
â€¢ From subcostal, rotate to long axis of IVC
â€¢ Shows: IVC size and collapsibility

effusion|tamponade|pericardial.content:
**Pericardial Effusion on POCUS**

**Appearance:**
â€¢ Anechoic (black) stripe surrounding heart
â€¢ Usually most prominent dependent (posterior/inferior)

**Quantification:**
â€¢ Small: <1 cm
â€¢ Moderate: 1-2 cm
â€¢ Large: >2 cm

**Tamponade findings:**
â€¢ RA collapse (systole) â€” earliest
â€¢ RV collapse (diastole) â€” more specific
â€¢ IVC plethora (dilated, <50% collapsible)
â€¢ Swinging heart (large effusions)

**Best views:**
â€¢ Subcostal (most dependent, often largest)
â€¢ PLAX (posterior effusion)
â€¢ A4C (inferior/lateral effusion)

rv|right|ventricle|dilation|strain.content:
**RV Assessment on POCUS**

**Normal RV:**
â€¢ Smaller than LV (RV:LV ratio <0.6)
â€¢ Crescent-shaped in PSAX
â€¢ Free wall thickness <5mm

**RV Dilation (acute pressure overload):**
â€¢ RV:LV ratio >1.0 (A4C or PSAX)
â€¢ Septal flattening (D-sign in PSAX)
â€¢ McConnell's sign: RV free wall akinesis with apical sparing

**Common causes of acute RV dilation:**
â€¢ Massive/submassive PE (most common in ED)
â€¢ RV infarct (inferior MI with ST elevation)

**Best views:**
â€¢ A4C (RV:LV size comparison)
â€¢ PSAX (septal motion, D-sign)

lv|left|ventricle|function|ef.content:
**LV Function Assessment**

**Qualitative (eyeball method):**
â€¢ Hyperdynamic: Endocardial surfaces nearly touch
â€¢ Normal: EF 50-70%, good wall motion
â€¢ Reduced: EF 30-50%, hypokinesis
â€¢ Severely reduced: EF <30%, minimal contraction

**Quantitative estimates:**
â€¢ Fractional shortening: (LVEDD - LVESD)/LVEDD (normal 25-45%)
â€¢ Visual EF estimation (practice required)

**Wall motion abnormalities:**
â€¢ Anterior/septal: LAD territory
â€¢ Inferior: RCA territory
â€¢ Lateral: LCx territory

**Best views:**
â€¢ PLAX (anterior septum, posterior wall)
â€¢ PSAX (all segments at different levels)
â€¢ A4C (lateral wall, apex)

default.content:
For this hypotensive patient with chest pain:

1. **Start with subcostal view** â€” best for pericardial effusion (patient supine, pain allowing)
2. **Check for effusion/tamponade** â€” anechoic stripe, RA/RV collapse
3. **Assess RV size** â€” PE can cause acute RV dilation
4. **Evaluate LV function** â€” is this cardiogenic shock?
5. **IVC for volume status** â€” dilated, non-collapsible = high CVP

**Differential based on echo findings:**
â€¢ Effusion with tamponade â†’ Pericardiocentesis
â€¢ RV dilation with septal shift â†’ Massive PE
â€¢ Severe LV dysfunction â†’ Cardiogenic shock

Need help with a specific view or finding?
